events.title: Welcome to the NGI Policy Summit 2020
events.text: Join us for a brief welcome from our partners at the City of Amsterdam and the Ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations of the Netherlands. Together, we'll take a look back at Amsterdam's role in the early days of the internet - and the challenges that lie ahead for all of Europe.

participants.name: Raymond Knops, Dutch Ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations

events.title: Visions for the future Internet: what if?
events.text: In this series of short lightning talks, we will hear from speakers about possible—and sometimes quirky—futures for the internet. Join us to share your own thoughts and visions for digital life in 2030.

events.title: Keynote: European Commission
events.text: Join us for the first keynote of the Summit, where we'll hear from the European Commission about their ambitions for the Next Generation Internet.

events.title: The case for a European data economy
events.text: A group discussion setting out a positive vision for Europe’s data economy, looking at data spaces and trusts, the concept of data sovereignty and the European Commission’s key initiatives in this space. We will focus on opportunities for Europe to build more equitable economic models by harnessing innovation, entrepreneurship and standard-setting powers.

participants.name: Jaya Klara Brekke, University of Durham

events.title: A digital roadmap for 2030: defining Europe’s role after COVID-19
events.text: A scene-setting panel discussion of the challenges and opportunities facing Europe and the Internet in the next decade. What does the Next Generation Europe agenda mean for digital policy and regulation? What geopolitical considerations should inform our approach to emerging technologies and markets? Join us as we map out the road to 2030 and touch on some of the Summit’s biggest questions, from data sovereignty to digital life after COVID-19.

participants.name: Thomas Zerdick, European Data Protection Supervisor

events.title: Decentralising the internet: the 'Blockchains for Social Good' prize
events.text: With the 'Blockchains for Social Good' Prize, the European Innovation Council (EIC) recognises and supports the recent efforts of developers and civil society to decentralise and apply blockchains for social innovation. Meet the winners of €5 million award and join us for a brief look at the six challenge areas that our innovators are tackling: traceability and fair trade, financial inclusion, decentralised circular economy, transparency of public processes, participation in democratic decision-making, and management of public records.

events.title: [Workshop] Digital identity
events.text: The Netherlands has recently developed a vision for digital identity that allows for experimentation. In this workshop, presented by officials from the Dutch Ministry of the Interior, participants will learn about this vision and opportunities for international cooperation in the realm of Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI). We will also discuss an international use case in the European Blockchain Partnership. Session produced and hosted by: Dutch Ministry of the Interior

participants.name: Wouter Welling, Dutch Ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations

events.title: [Workshop] Biometrics and facial recognition in cities
events.text: Across the EU, facial recognition and other biometric processing technologies are increasingly being used in public spaces across cities, with risks that they can violate people's fundamental rights. In this special session with European Digital Rights (EDRi) - a network of 44 civil society digital rights organisations – we will explore the present situation, and together with policy makers across Europe, discusses different scenarios of the roles that biometrics might play in cities in the near future. We will discuss whether cities can actually use such technologies in a privacy-friendly way or if they should abolish them altogether. We will also explore the impact on other fundamental rights, such as non-discrimination, and freedoms to assemble and express ourselves. The goal of this meeting is to update policymakers and involve them into a productive conversation on privacy in cities. Session produced and hosted by: City of Amsterdam and European Digital Rights (EDRi)

participants.name: Aik van Eemeren, City Of Amsterdam

events.title: [Workshop] Learning from 'critical making' - Good Things for the Next Generation Internet
events.text: By connecting products to the internet — by adding a data layer to the physical world, and by physically manifesting the internet — we change the very nature of the things themselves. And for the last decade or two, just about everything has been connected in one way or another. At ThingsCon, we’ve been exploring how to do so more responsibly, and…better. 'Critical making' is a crucial part of the mix of gathering understanding in connected products over the years. ThingsCon has built a reputation to mix critical making with policy thinking and in this session, we would like to share what we've learned from years of involving the makers’ community to foster the creation of a responsible IoT. Making as a way of understanding and grounding, or just as a way to bring home the policy discussions.  Session produced and hosted by: ThingsCon Network

participants.name: Andrea Krajewski, University of Applied Sciences Darmstadt

events.title: [Workshop] Digital transformation in the public sector: challenge based public private partnership and cooperation
events.text: The public sector is key to digital transformation. Public authorities are a major partner in solving societal challenges. Public private partnerships are very common in areas such as care, energy and mobility and in the use key technologies (Artificial Intelligence). Another type of cooperation is challenging SME’s to come up with solutions for public tasks. Cities are at the forefront of new forms of interaction with private partners due to the variety of  public tasks. Torino is a city in Italy with an excellent track in innovation in the public sector. Through Torino City Lab the city uses 'Calls for challenge' and 'experimentation contracts' to promote the co-development and testing of innovative solutions of public interest by the private sector. This of course is a way to constantly gather market intelligence,  linking the role of testing/co-development at the pre-commercial phase and PPI.The ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations has a link to digital society and uses pre commercial procurement to stimulate solving societal challenges with key technologies (Blockchain and AI). Marieke van Putten and Elena Deambrogio give presentations on how their organizations stimulate (digital) innovation. They challenge the participants in how to use the potential of private enterprises and the best way to realize deployment/implementation. Session produced and hosted by: Dutch Ministry of the Interior

participants.name: Marieke van Putten, Dutch Ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations

events.title: [Workshop] Data-sharing in cities
events.text: Join us for a workshop for city and regional stakeholders that explores the application of digital rights in local data-sharing platforms throughout planning, implementation, and evolution. Looking at case studies from Toronto, Zaragoza, Berlin, Newcastle, Rennes, Bordeaux, and Helsinki, we will discuss how city platforms for data-sharing are created from different building blocks (policies, processes, infrastructures, and actions) to extract value from urban big data.

participants.name: Daniel Sarasa Funes, Eurocities Data Working Group
Ryan Kurtzman, City of Long Beach, California

events.title: [Workshop] Transatlantic crossings: the future of EU-US data flows
events.text: Personal data privacy management across the Atlantic is among the core topics tackled by the Think NEXUS project. Together with experts from both Europe and the US, we explore the impact of the latest European decision on the EU-US Privacy Shield agreement. Session produced and hosted by: Think NEXUS and GAC Group

events.title: [Evening programme] What your face reveals - the story of HowNormalAmI.eu
events.text: In this session, Dutch media artist Tijmen Schep will launch his latest work - an online interactive documentary that judges you through your webcam, and explains how face detection algorithms are invisibly pervading our lives. Can we really asses someone's beauty, BMI or even life expectancy from just a photo of their face? After experiencing his creation, we'll dive into the 'making of' and emerge with a better understanding of what face detection AI can - and cannot -  do.

events.title: [Workshop] Zenroom: cryptography and smart contracts in human language
events.text: Zenroom is a tiny secure execution environment that integrates into any platform and application, even on a chip or a web page. It can authenticate, authorise access and execute human-readable smart contracts for blockchains, databases and much more. It helps to develop cryptography by keeping it simple, understandable and maintainable. Session produced and hosted by: Dyne.org

events.title: [Workshop] Privacy and trust: trends in experiments in EU-US research and innovation
events.text: Collaboration on privacy, trust and decentralised data governance is key to improving EU-US research and generating impacts at a pan-European level. Within this space, NGIAtlantic.eu has funded six projects aiming to increase privacy and trust by leveraging AI, blockchain, 5G, big data and IoT technologies. This workshop will provide policymakers with an overview of the major trends and trajectories in EU-US research collaboration and provides important context for NGI-related policy development. NGIAtlantic.eu’s projects will pitch their experiments, present their initial results and showcase the Twinning Lab, an on-line space for researchers, innovators and start-ups to establish complementary partnerships with transatlantic actors to address NGI challenges. Session produced and hosted by: NGIAtlantic.eu

participants.name: James Clarke, Waterford Institute of Technology

events.title: [Evening programme] Futurotheque – a trip to the future
events.text: Augmented reality artist Sander Veenhof and Leonieke Verhoog, program manager PublicSpaces are taking you on a trip to the future with their speculative fiction installation, the Futurotheque. Our future will be filled with augmented reality applications in phones, glasses, lenses and other devices. Imagine going around with glasses that help you with all your information and entertainment needs, that can guide you wherever you are, and that can make decisions for you. What does that mean for our daily life? It is not so much about how we are going to respond to those new tech tools, as well as how they will respond to us. What agency do we keep, and what do we hand over to these new systems? Enter the Futurotheque to be inspired, amazed or appalled – and make up your own mind.

events.title: [Evening programme] Ask me anything
events.text: In this session, you can ask the CTOs of two major European cities anything – get their view on tech developments, policy decisions, smart cities, face recognition, budgets, staff, training, audience participation and anything else you want to ask.

events.title: [Workshop] (Dis)connected future: an immersive simulation
events.text: In this immersive futures workshop we will tackle the key design choices for the future internet. We will collectively shape the evolution of the next generation internet letting our audience drive the simulation and exploring what future scenarios their decisions might yield. Join us to peek into the future! Session produced and hosted by: Nesta Italia

events.title: [Workshop] Public control over AI: the how and why of accountable AI
events.text: AI is a strategic technology that could offer many benefits for citizens, companies and society as a whole — provided it is people-centric, accountable, sustainable and respects fundamental rights and values. How can we exert the right controls to make sure that these tools are only used in ways that are transparent, just, and accountable? Join this session for lightning talks by civil society groups, research institutes, and non profit organizations with their ‘big ideas’ for public oversight and control over AI. Session produced and hosted by: Mozilla, AI Now and AlgorithmWatch

participants.name: Linda van de Fliert, City Of Amsterdam

events.title: [Workshop] Ethnography and the internet: collective intelligence insights for digital policy
events.text: NGI Forward will present how they use community-building and Semantic Social Network Analysis to inform policy research for the Next Generation Internet. We will then move into a hands-on workshop and teach participants how to explore network visualisations for novelty and policy insights, based on community discussions about the future internet on the Edgeryders online platform. Session produced and hosted by: Edgeryders

events.title: [Workshop] Public control over AI: a public AI register
events.text: Join us for a Q&A with Meeri Haataja of Saidot, a platform enabling AI transparency and accountability. Meeri Haataja will demonstrate the algorithmic and AI registers of the cities of Amsterdam and Helsinki that Saidots platform made possible, and you can ask her anything about what is needed to realize AI transparency within your own organisation. Session produced and hosted by: Saidot

events.title: [Workshop] Public control over AI: Procurement conditions for AI and algorithms
events.text: Procurement conditions is a very powerful and practical instrument for the public sector to assure AI-enabled systems comply with fundamental rights and democratic values. That’s why the City of Amsterdam asked ICT Law specialist Jeroen Naves, together with other experts, to draft the very first standard contractual clauses for AI and algorithms. Jeroen Naves will answer all your questions about how these legal definitions and provisions can help us gain public control over AI.  Session produced and hosted by: Pels Rijcken

events.title: [Workshop] Public control over AI: Data Ethics Decision Aid (DEDA)
events.text: Get ready for a crash course in data ethics decision making. DEDA helps data analysts, project managers and policy makers to recognize ethical issues in data projects, data management and data policies. DEDA is a tool-kit facilitating initial brainstorming sessions to map ethical issues in data projects, documenting the deliberation process and furthering accountability towards the various stakeholders and the public.  Session produced and hosted by: Utrecht Data School

participants.name: Mirko Tobias Schäfer, Utrecht Data School

events.title: [Workshop] Mapping the tech world and supporting policy with text-mining
events.text: Cutting through the noise of daily news and identifying the most important policy issues can be a major challenge. In this workshop, we present simple text-mining tools developed in the NGI Forward project and explore recent trends in tech news. Through a series of deep dives into our data, we will discuss some of the most pressing tech challenges on people's minds, such as Ethical AI or contact-tracing. For a sneak peek at our research, visit: https://fwd.delabapps.eu/ and https://covid.delabapps.eu/ Session produced and hosted by: DELab

events.title: [Workshop] Beyond trust: our information ecosystem under pressure
events.text: This interactive workshop outlines how AI, the Internet of Everything and profiling (your new identity) lead to alternative realities and truths. The core of our information ecosystem is globalized and digitized, governed by algorithms, with no one in control or accountable. Many point out that this system of which we are all part is increasingly corrupted. How can we preserve trust? Attendees will be asked to share and discuss (their) ideas. Session produced and hosted by: Dutch Police

participants.name: Manon den Dunnen, Dutch National Police

events.title: Have I still got news for you? Preserving trust, journalism and the public sphere
events.text: Join us for a thought-provoking conversation about the future of journalism and what Europe can do to avert the continued erosion of public trust in the digital sphere.

events.title: Europe's twin transition: creating a sustainable digital future
events.text: The defining challenge of this decade will be the twin transition towards a more sustainable and connected future. Join us for a conversation about how we can reduce the internet's hidden environmental costs and harness its transformative potential for environmental action.

events.title: Solutions or solutionism? The role of technology in times of crisis
events.text: Join us for an examination of the role that the internet and emerging technologies can play in responding to crises. What can we do to better prepare ourselves for future systemic shocks? And how do we ensure that technology targets complex problems effectively, without excluding people or causing unintended harm?

events.title: Tackling the city challenge: cities for digital rights
events.text: From ensuring the fairness of AI-assisted decisionmaking to the sustainability challenge of IoT-enabled smart cities - how we design the Next Generation Internet will have a significant impact on the daily lives of city dwellers. Join the City Coalition for Digital Rights (CC4DR) for the launch of the City Challenge and an interactive look at some of the European cities that are already pursuing meaningful digital transformation by putting people and their environment first.

events.title: Who is who? The future of digital identity, trust and privacy
events.text: Questions of identity, trust and data ownership are at the core of many of the internet's oldest and most formidable challenges. But they also hold great potential to empower individuals and make the internet more human-centric. Join us for a look at the latest developments in trust and identity in Europe and beyond - from nascent use cases to the challenges still in front of us.

participants.name: Lalana Kagal, Massachusetts Institute of Technology

events.title: Towards a more inclusive internet: a call to action
events.text: In this interactive closing session, we will explore how the internet of the future can, once again, become a driver for inclusion and social empowerment - both in Europe and at a global scale.
